heading: team-letter
type: welcome evolution approach partners communities reach impact team contact
html:
Letter from the Team



From 2008 to 2013, the Knowledge-Driven Microenterprise Development (KDMD) Project supported USAID in developing its knowledge management and learning capacities. At its core, knowledge management is about sharing lessons learned and best practices – which is why we are excited to present our experiences and achievements through this interactive final report.

KDMD was originally created as a knowledge management project under the former Microenterprise Development office (now E3/MPEP/MD) with the purpose of helping international development practitioners learn, coordinate, and distribute foreign assistance more effectively. We began with just eight full-time staff assisting USAID in the management of seminars and creation of learning products. However, as we gained recognition for the quality and importance of this work, 12 additional USAID operating units bought into our project and our staff grew three-fold.

Along the way, we’ve increased our skill set to encompass innovative techniques such as facilitating online seminar participation, using social media to share best practices, and creating online learning communities. As the field of knowledge management has evolved, the KDMD team has stayed informed of leading trends and opportunities to engage international development stakeholders in new and creative ways that foster learning and maximize the impact of development efforts.

Over the years, KDMD played a major role in promoting knowledge management and learning at USAID and in the broader international development community. Our knowledge products have attracted thousands of participants, users, and viewers. To accomplish this, our team spent thousands of hours supporting our partners – and we’re proud to share the results.

As you scroll through this final report, you’ll see a story of the challenges that KDMD faced, our solutions, our partners in learning, what we’ve learned, and our impact. We hope you’ll continue our story by reflecting on how our experiences relate to your own work and that you’ll be inspired to share these lessons with others.

Sincerely,

heading: team-letter
type: approach partners communities reach impact team contact
html: Successful international development requires social and human change. During the past 5 years, it has been our job to continuously adapt to these changing needs. Over the life of the project, KDMD has tripled our number of USAID partners and have committed to delivering cutting-edge, best-in-class solutions to USAID's knowledge management needs.

heading: team-letter
html: Building Communities

heading: team-letter
html: People have always been at the center of the work we do. KDMD has brought international development professionals together across space and time to share ideas and information. In order to facilitate a lasting conversation within our communities, KDMD has developed exciting learning products that extend the reach of foreign assistance.

heading: team-letter
html:
KDMD provides great opportunities to hear experts speak about their work and research results. Their Q&A provide an insight into participants' experiences. It presents a sense of community.
KDMD has been FIELD-Support’s primary vehicle for disseminating and distributing key findings, lessons, and methodologies that are developed under the LWA—especially to its targeted audiences: the practitioner community.
KDMD has approached our partnership with the utmost professionalism and commitment to ensure high quality results. Flexible, responsive and positive, it has been an absolute pleasure to work with your team.
Online vs. In-Person Audience

html: Our Reach

heading: team-letter
html: KDMD understands that people learn in different ways. That means traditional approaches won't do. Our creativity knows no bounds when it comes to designing engaging events and producing innovative, digital products which are spread far and wide.

heading: team-letter
html:
Our Influence



KDMD has revolutionized the way development practitioners connect with each other, significantly influencing how knowledge management is understood across USAID. This project has demonstrated that “knowledge management” is a technical field unto itself. Now more than ever, programs are being designed with a KM component to maximize learning and ultimately, to achieve better development outcomes.

heading: team-letter
html:
Define what success will look like in excruciating detail.

Scoping is as much about understanding the client as the objectives of an activity.

Adapt the 'lessons learned' to your style--they're meant as a guide.

Don't confuse the tool with the outcome. Don't oversimplify your planning to one tool. Think bigger!

Post-activity reflections are never a waste of time.

KM is about behavior change; it can't be outsourced.

Look for ways to build on and connect with existing activities/platforms before you start a new one.

People prefer to consume information in different ways, so think creatively about repackaging content.

Collaboration is a powerful thing. Your results will be so much better when you involve others in the process.

Listen to your audience. Get the participants' perspective.

heading: team-letter
html: Contact

heading: team-letter
html:
Disclaimer

Since the KDMD project officially began in 2008, data collection processes have significantly evolved and expanded over the years. The authors of this report used as many sources as possible to synthesize the project’s accomplishments, but they also acknowledge that in many cases, data was not available in all years for all programs. In order to illustrate the broad scope of KDMD’s work, the calculation of metrics across this report used a robust mixture of methods, tools and resources. The following is an illustrative list of some methods and tools used:


  • Activity reports
  • Google Analytics
  • Surveys with staff and other stakeholders
  • Project billing/staffing records
  • USAID University Training Course Enrollment Data
  • Adobe Connect analytics
  • After Action Review records
  • KDMD Training Sign in Sheets

Due to incomplete datasets, not all activities were uniformly documented with the same tools, resulting in some missing data points. In the case of missing data for a documented activity, an average across other similar activities was used as a proxy in the calculation of these overall metrics.


This final report was produced for review by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) under the Knowledge-Driven Microenterprise Development (KDMD) project, implemented by the QED Group LLC (Contract #EEM-C00-08-00004-00). The views expressed are those of the authors and do not represent the views of the U.S. Agency for International Development of the United States Government.
